For every positive natural number `k`, there exist infinitely many prime numbers `p` such that `p` is congruent to 1 modulo `k`.

name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime_modEq_one
docString: For every positive natural number `k`, there exist infinitely many prime numbers `p` such that `p` is congruent to 1 modulo `k`.

This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

For every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p > n`.

name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes

This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `p`, the number of natural numbers in the open interval `(0, n]` that are divisible by `p` is exactly `n / p`. This is determined by filtering the set of natural numbers in `(0, n]` to include only those that are divisible by `p`, and then counting the cardinality of this filtered set.

type: ‚àÄ (n p : ‚Ñï), (Finset.filter (fun x => p ‚à£ x) (Finset.Ioc 0 n)).card = n / p
name: Nat.Ioc_filter_dvd_card_eq_div
docString: This theorem states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `p`, the number of natural numbers in the open interval `(0, n]` that are divisible by `p` is exactly `n / p`. This is determined by filtering the set of natural numbers in `(0, n]` to include only those that are divisible by `p`, and then counting the cardinality of this filtered set.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ‚Ñï) ‚Üí [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ‚àà s] ‚Üí [inst : Infinite ‚Üës] ‚Üí Denumerable ‚Üës

docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

The number of natural numbers in the range [1, n] that are multiples of p is equal to the integer division n by p.

type: ‚àÄ (n p : ‚Ñï), (Finset.filter (fun e => p ‚à£ e + 1) (Finset.range n)).card = n / p
name: Nat.card_multiples
docString: The number of natural numbers in the range [1, n] that are multiples of p is equal to the integer division n by p.

This theorem states that for any finite power series `p`, if `p m` is equal to zero for all `m` greater than or equal to a certain natural number `n`, then the sum of the series `p` can be represented as a formal power series on an open ball centered at `0` with radius `‚àû` and `n` terms. Here, `ùïú` is the field of scalars, `E` and `F` are normed spaces over `ùïú`, which are also normed additive commutative groups.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {F : Type u_3} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú E] [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ùïú F]
  (p : FormalMultilinearSeries ùïú E F) {n : ‚Ñï}, (‚àÄ (m : ‚Ñï), n ‚â§ m ‚Üí p m = 0) ‚Üí HasFiniteFPowerSeriesOnBall p.sum p 0 n ‚ä§
name: FormalMultilinearSeries.hasFiniteFPowerSeriesOnBall_of_finite

For all natural numbers n and p, the p-th power of the multiplicity of p in the prime factorization of n divides n.

name: Nat.ord_proj_dvd
docString: For all natural numbers n and p, the p-th power of the multiplicity of p in the prime factorization of n divides n.

This theorem states that a `p`-series over the set of integers `‚Ñ§` is summable if and only if `p` is greater than 1. Here, summability refers to the series having a finite sum, and a `p`-series is a series of the form 1/n^p. In mathematical notation, this is expressed as `‚àë (1/n^p) converges iff p > 1`.

name: Real.summable_one_div_int_pow

A number satisfying the Liouville condition with exponent `p > 1` is an irrational number.

type: ‚àÄ {p x : ‚Ñù}, LiouvilleWith p x ‚Üí 1 < p ‚Üí Irrational x

docString: A number satisfying the Liouville condition with exponent `p > 1` is an irrational number.

The number of occurrences of p in the factor multiset of m
is the same as the p-adic valuation of m.

type: ‚àÄ (m : ‚Ñï+) (p : Nat.Primes) (k : ‚Ñï), ‚Üëp ^ k ‚à£ m ‚Üî k ‚â§ Multiset.count p (PNat.factorMultiset m)

is the same as the p-adic valuation of m.
